Authors:
Nohemi Carreras-Villaseñor, Jose Benjamin Rodríguez-Haas,
Luis Alberto Martínez-Rodríguez, Alan Josue Pérez-Lira, Enrique
Ibarra-Laclette, Emanuel Villafan, Ana Patricia Castillo-Díaz, Luis
Arturo Ibarra-Juarez, Edgar David Carrillo-Hernandez, Diana
Sánchez-Rangel
Title:
Pathogenic profile of two Fusarium sp. strains isolated from
the ambrosia beetle Xylosandrus morigerus
Keywords:
ambrosia beetle, Fusarium solani species complex, Ambrosia
Fusarium Clade
Abstract:
Ambrosia beetles are causal agents of important plant
diseases and have been considered as a threat to forest ecosystems,
agriculture and timber industry. Several factors have been suggested as
promoters of the pathogenic behavior of ambrosia beetles, one of them is
the nature of the fungal mutualist and its ability to establish an
infectious process. In Mexico, Xylosandrus morigerus is an invasive
ambrosia beetle provoking damage in many agroecosystems. Herein, two
different morphotypes of Fusarium sp. isolated from X. morigerus are
reported. Fusarium sp. associated to X. morigerus strains belong to the
Fusarium solani species complex (FSSC) but do not to the Ambrosia
Fusarium clade (AFC). Both strains are virulent to different forest and
agronomic species in both tissue and host specific manner; the
extracellular proteases profile suggest differences in gene regulation.
This study shows importance of considering the beetles as vectors of
different morphotypes of fungal plant pathogens with different
pathogenic abilities, highlighting the relevance of the fungal mutualist
as factor for the ambrosia complex becoming pest.
